publicationStmt.authority: The Estate of Virginia Woolf, administered by the Society of Authors

handNote.p: Holograph writing by the documents' main hand, Virginia Woolf

msIdentifier.repository: Henry W. and Albert A. Berg Collection of English and American Literature

physDesc.p: M50. Anon. Typescript fragment, with the author's ms. corrections, unsigned and undated. 9p. Paginated 1-9.

correction.p: Apparent errors have been explicitly corrected in / tags, wrapped in a element.

normalization.p: Where appropriate, spelling and punctuation have been modernised using / tags, wrapped in a element.

interpretation.p: Names and references to places and literary works have been wrapped in tags which link to annotations and secondary material.

projectDesc.p: Text encoded as part of 'The Digital "Anon": A Digital Genetic Edition of Virginia Woolf's Final Essays'. This project, funded by Leverhulme Grant ECF-2022-602, seeks to construct a TEI-XML based digital edition of the drafts of 'Anon' and 'The Reader', among the final documents Woolf wrote before her death.

p.l: ANON.
"For many centuries afte after Britain became an island" the
historian says ""the untamed forest was king. Its moist

l.quote: and mossy floor was hidden from Heavens eye by a close drawn

p.l: curtain woven of innumerable tree tops." On those matted
boughs innumerable birds sang; but their song was only heard
by a few skin clad hunters in the lcearings clearings . Did the desire
to sing come to one of those huntsmen because he heard the
birds sing, and so rested his axe against the tree for a
moment? But the tree had to be felled; and a hut made
from its branches before the human voice sang too.

quote.l: By a bank as I lay
And me thought in her lay
She said, winter was past, hey ho!

p.l: The voice that broke the sielnce silence of the forests was
the voice of Anon. Some one heard the song and re embered remembered it
for it was later wrteen written down, beautifully on parchment.
Thus the singer had his audience, but the audience was so
little interested in his name that he never thought to give
it. For the audience was itself the singer; Terly terlow"
they sand; and "By, by lullay" filling in the pauses,
helping out with a chorus. Every body shared in the emotion
of Anons song, and supplied the story. Anon sang because
spring has come; or winter is gone; because he loves; because
he is hungry, or lustful; or merry. or because he adores
some God. Anon is sometimes man; sometimes woman. He is the
common voice singing out of doors, He has no house. He l ves lives
a r ming roaming life crossing the fields, mounting the hills,
lying under the hawthown to listen to the nightigale nightingale .
By shutting out a chimney or a factory we can still
see what Anon saw-- the bird haunted reed whispering fen,
the down and the green scar never quite not yet healed along which
he came when he made his journeys. He was a simple singer,
lifting a song or a story from other peoples lips and lettig letting
the audience join in the chorus. Somemimes Sometimes he made a few lines
that exactly matched his emotion--
but there is no name mae name to that song.
Then when the houses had come together in some
lcearing clearing in a ring and roads, often flooded, often deep in
mud, led from hxxxx the cottage ot the Manor, from the Manor
to the Church in the middle, along the roads came minstersl minstrels
jugglers, bear leaders, singing their songs at the back door
to the farm hands and the maid servants in the uncouth
jargon of their native tongue.
Up stairs they spoke French. Anons words were as
uncouth to the master and mistress as to us. Anon
singing at yhe the back door was despsied despised . He had no name;
he had no place, yet even if they felt contempt for the
singer ?????man who made songs, they tolerated him. Even Kings and Queens
